narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Light-Matter Interactions: Classical foundations of material response: Electromagnetic waves and energy storage in dispersive systems; Microscopic origins of susceptibility; Greens functions and causality; Kramers Kronig relations; Oscillator strength and summing rules; Classical Lorentz, Drude, Drude-Lorentz models; Classical treatment nonlinear optical susceptibilities. Linear and nonlinear wave propagation: Dispersion and dispersive wave propagation; Energy storage and transport; Spatial dispersion wave propagation in effective media; Kerr nonlinearities; Temporal and spatial solitons; Nonlinearly coupled waves; Parametric amplification. Amplifiers and lasers: Absorption, spontaneous, and stimulated emission; Conditions for laser oscillation; Noise in optical amplifiers; Saturation phenomena; Relaxation oscillations; Synchronization of oscillators; Nonlinear couplings; Introduction to parametric amplification and oscillation. Quantum foundations: Selection rules in atoms and solids; Quantum treatment of linear and nonlinear susceptibility; Two-level atom; Virtual transitions and multi-photon interactions; Heisenberg equation of motion; Canonical field quantization; Absorption, spontaneous, and stimulated emission Nonlinear light-scattering processes: Wave-mixing processes; Multi-photon absorption; Raman processes and Raman-like processes; Brillouin interactions; Forces and optomechanical interactions. Semiconductor and metal optics: Direct and indirect bandgap absorption; Excitons; Defect centers; Plasma-optic effect; Quantum confinement; Free carrier dispersion; Inter-band transitions; Plasmons. Photon-phonon coupling: IR-active vibrational resonances; Restrahlen bands; Polaritons; Polarons; Lattice absorption; Spontaneous and stimulated Raman scattering; Spontaneous and stimulated Brillouin interactions etc... on the syllabus
Gained some knowledge of various potential areas of research.
Light-matter interaction phenomena and general Electromagntism.
Lorentz oscillator model, some mathematical techniques

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor really needs to improve his handwriting in notes.
Strengths: Great professor, puts lot of effort into course, good problem sets, assumes only basic EM and QM

Lectures were kind of messy. A lot of stuff was behind schedule. I think the reason for this is because the instructor tried to cater to every single student especially those who asked a lot of questions during lecture. I learnt a lot from his answers and greatly appreciated them, however, I think this could be better managed in terms of perhaps having separate sessions for questions etc.
The course is not so well-organized.
I think a more traditional slide show would be better than OneNote. It's too busy.
Wish it was a more in-depth treatment as opposed to an overview of topics

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I took it as an undergrad Junior with QM and EM, while also taking statmech/thermo. Very accessible, but the 4-5 problem sets and final project are no joke.
Only if they are interested in this particular area for research.
